post.author: mwrock
post.title: Adding CSS Inheritance Resolution to RequestReduce Sprite Generation Process
post.content:
UPDATE: This functionality was released on 1/9/12 in v1.7.0.

Currently RequestReduce is unable to sprite alot of background images because of its limitation of treating each css class as an atomic unit. Inheritable dimensions and padding is lost which either makes an image unspritable by RequestReduce or the sprite is malformed because of improperly calculated dimensions.

Further, pre-sprited images in a document about to be reduced are often malformed and rendered in a distorted fashion because it is common practice to place the background url in one widely inherited class and have more specific classes define just the background-position of the individual image in the sprite. This makes many initial renderings using RequestReduce give a bad first impression especially if the user does not read the wikis on preparing the sprites and spriting requirements here and here. It can also make the exercise of converting docs to be compatible with RR spriting a time consuming and tedious endeavor.

I had initially thought this was a small edge case but it is proving to be an all too common problem and I think the adoption story could be dramatically improved by adding this feature. This is the one feature that can break the RequestReduce golden rule: do not break the page I am reducing. The addition of this feature can prevent this.

Unfortunately it is not a small effort. However it is not monumental either.

comment.author: Dominik Schlosser
comment.content:
Hey Matt,
we use RequestReduce for Image-Spriting and are very satisfied so far. The only drawback is that css inheritance is not supported which forces our designers to do weird things.
So my question is if you can give as an ETA of this feature?

comment.author: Matt Wrock
comment.content:
Hi Dominik,
I'm glad you are finding RequestReduce useful. Having had to migrate several css files to RequestReduce and tweak the classes to get the images sprited correctly, I recognize and appretiate that this is a pain point which I hope is smaller than the pain of creating and maintaining sprites from scratch.
Currently I'm finishing up integrating .less, sass and coffee compilation. Perhaps using some .less conventions may ease some of this pain. I intend to begin the inheritance work immediately afterwards so beginning next week.
This will be a bigger work item and may take a couple weeks depending on my schedule. I also may run into some snags. Somehow I think there are gonna be gotchas that I'm not currently considering that I'll find once I start implementing. We'll see.
Anyways, I certainly hope to have this out my month's end.

comment.author: Dominik Schlosser
comment.content:
Thank you for responding this fast.
This is a very valuable information to us and saves us from a lot of work :-)

comment.content: Dominik: This was released today in v1.7.0.
